Article.ArticleTitle: Synthesis, characterization and magnetic studies on mono-, di-, and tri-nuclear Cu(ii) complexes of a new versatile diazine ligand.

AbstractText: The synthesis and coordination chemistry of a new open-chain diazine ligand (L4H<sub>2</sub>) containing bipyridine, oxime and hydrazone functionalities is reported. Reaction of L4H<sub>2</sub> with CuCl<sub>2</sub>·2H<sub>2</sub>O affords the mononuclear complex [Cu(L4H<sub>2</sub>)Cl<sub>2</sub>] (1) in which the ligand acts as a neutral tridentate N,N',N'' donor, whereas treatment with a large excess of CuCl<sub>2</sub>·2H<sub>2</sub>O affords the dinuclear complex [Cu<sub>2</sub>(L4H)Cl<sub>3</sub>(CH<sub>3</sub>OH)(H<sub>2</sub>O)] (2) in which the ligand is singly-deprotonated at the diazine, offering N,N',N'' and N,N' donor sets to two Cu(ii) ions. Reaction with Cu(NO<sub>3</sub>)<sub>2</sub>·3H<sub>2</sub>O yields the trinuclear complex, [Cu<sub>3</sub>(L4H)<sub>2</sub>(CH<sub>3</sub>OH)<sub>4</sub>(NO<sub>3</sub>)<sub>4</sub>] (3) in which the ligand is again singly deprotonated, but now presents a tetradentate N,N',N'',N'''-donor set to the first Cu(ii) and behaves as an N,O-chelate to a second Cu(ii), with a conformational change from cis to trans at the diazine moiety. When the latter reaction is repeated in the presence of a mild base, a second trinuclear complex is isolated, [Cu<sub>3</sub>(L4)<sub>2</sub>(CH<sub>3</sub>CH<sub>2</sub>OH)](NO<sub>3</sub>)<sub>2</sub> (4) in which both the diazine and oxime functionalities of the ligand are deprotonated which subsequently bridges all three Cu(ii) ions, acting as an N,N',N'' donor to the first Cu(ii), a N,N' donor to a second Cu(ii) (similar to 2) and as a terminal O-donor to a third Cu(ii) ion. The Cu(ii) ions are linked mutually cis via the two-atom diazine bridge in the case of 2 and 4 and trans in the case of 3. Magnetic studies reveal the presence of weak ferromagnetic interactions in 2 (g = 2.2, J/k = +12.8 K) and strong antiferromagnetic interactions in both 3 and 4 (g = 2.093 J/k = -140 K and g = 2.24 J/k = -300 K respectively).
